pages.name: Prokofiev: Cinderella
pages.descriptionShort: The family-friendly Cinderella ballet brings fairy tale magic from the Czech Republic to Tampere. The music by Prokofiev is performed by the Tampere Philharmonic Orchestra.
pages.descriptionLong:
The Ballet of National Theatre Brno & The Tampere Philharmonic Orchestra:

Prokofiev: Cinderella

Tampere Hall, Main Auditorium


Music by Sergei Prokofiev

Choreography and direction by Markéta Pimek Habalová

Set design by David Janošek

Costumes by Pavel Knolle

Soloists and dance company Brno National Theatre Ballet

Music performed by Tampere Philharmonic Orchestra


The beloved tale of Cinderella is one of the world’s oldest fairy tales, captivating both children and adults alike. In Tampere, the magic of the story comes alive through the skilled dancers of the Ballet of the National Theatre Brno, Sergei Prokofiev’s extraordinary music performed by the Tampere Philharmonic Orchestra, and breathtaking visual storytelling.


The Cinderella ballet will be performed at Tampere Hall in three shows on Friday, November 21, and Saturday, November 22, 2025. The production, which respects tradition while offering a fresh take on the art, combines the good fairy godmother, magical carriage, and the lost ball gown slipper in beautiful choreography and tender storytelling. The familiar story and delightful characters make Cinderella a perfect choice for a first-time ballet experience.


Duration: Approx. 3 hours, including an intermission. Recommended for viewers over 6 years old.


Tickets:

Standard tickets: 68/58/48 €

Seniors: 62/52/42 €

Students and youth: 45 €

Children (up to 13 years old): 35 €


Event changes may occur. Production by Tampere Hall, in collaboration with the Tampere Philharmonic Orchestra.

pages.name: Kanae Nozawa Erhu Concert
pages.descriptionShort: Following her successful 2024 Finland tour, Kanae Nozawa returns with an enchanting erhu concert!
pages.descriptionLong:
Following her successful 2024 Finland tour, Kanae Nozawa returns with an enchanting erhu concert! Praised as "the most beautiful concert ever heard" by audiences, Kanae will captivate you with her expressive erhu and gentle vocals. The expressive sound of the erhu, the "Chinese violin," is familiar to many from movie and video game music, and its versatile tone truly shines in Kanae Nozawa’s performance. Joined by renowned composer Tamiya Terashima on keyboard, the concert will feature Studio Ghibli classics like Howl's Moving Castle and My Neighbor Totoro, as well as other beloved Japanese anime songs. Additionally, Tamiya Terashima, known for composing the music for Tales from Earthsea, will have his works performed, alongside traditional melodies and Kanae’s original compositions. This promises to be a magical night of music!


Tickets: https://www.hs.fi/menokone/tickets/177741/908381/tickets

pages.name: Tampere Philharmonic Orchestra: One Thousand and One Nights
pages.descriptionShort: Matthew Halls leads a magical concert where Rimsky-Korsakov’s Scheherazade meets Singh Degun’s sitar concerto Arya and Debussy’s sensual Afternoon of a Faun.
pages.descriptionLong:
Matthew Halls, conductor 

Jasdeep Singh Degun, sitar 


Claude Debussy: Afternoon of the Faun 

Jasdeep Singh Degun: Arya, concerto for sitar and orchestra, Finnish premiere 

Nikolai Rimsky-Korsakov: Scheherazade 


Nikolai Rimsky-Korsakov composed his crowning work, Scheherazade, in 1888. Inspired by the tales of One Thousand and One Nights, this symphonic suite takes the listener on a magical journey through the folktales of the Middle East. Only six years later, Claude Debussy made history with Afternoon of a Faun, where the elusive harmonies mark the dawn of modern music. Award-winning British composer and sitar virtuoso Jasdeep Singh Degun ties his North Indian roots to Western music. His sitar concerto Arya symbolizes the experiences of separation and unity: a lone hero challenges a group of like-minded individuals in a confrontation, culminating in a deep sense of connection. 


Season series concert | includes an intermission | pre-concert talk at 6 PM


Tickets: adults 34 € / pensioners 26 € / students, unemployed and conscripts 16 € / children under 18 years 10 €


You can buy tickets from the Tampere Hall ticket office, Aplodi and the Lippupiste online store (Lippupiste adds service and order fees to the ticket prices, along with possible delivery and payment method charges).

pages.name: Tampere Philharmonic Orchestra: Independence Day concert – Northern Song
pages.descriptionShort: The Independence Day concert features highlights of Finnish music, from Sibelius’s Finlandia and Rautavaara’s Cantus Arcticus to a new work by Tampere-based composer Petri Nieminen.
pages.descriptionLong:
Erle Kont, conductor 

Johannes Põlda, violin 


Erkki Melartin: Symphony No. 5, “Sinfonia brevis”: movement I Moderato 

Petri Nieminen: new work, world premiere, commissioned by Tampere Philharmonic 

Jean Sibelius: Two Humoresques for Violin and Orchestra, Op. 87 

Einojuhani Rautavaara: Cantus Arcticus, Concerto for Birds and Orchestra 

Jean Sibelius: Finlandia  


Einojuhani Rautavaara’s Cantus Arcticus is perhaps the most internationally recognized Finnish composition after Sibelius. Its bird songs soaring above the orchestra create a magical harmony between nature and humanity. Erkki Melartin, a central figure in Finnish Romanticism, celebrates his 150th anniversary. His symphonic music reflects cosmopolitan grandeur, evoking composers like Pyotr Tchaikovsky and Gustav Mahler. Tampere Philharmonic’s concertmaster Johannes Põlda will perform Sibelius's Humoresques, while Petri Nieminen's latest composition receives its world premiere. Young talent Erle Kont conducts the concert, ensuring that it is a collection of unforgettable moments. 


Please note that this concert is not part of the season series. No Pre-concert talk.


Tickets: adults 34 € / pensioners 26 € / students, unemployed and conscripts 16 € / children under 18 years 10 €

pages.name: Tanssiteatteri MD: Aliveness
pages.descriptionShort: This is the flower of a Partisan, died for freedom. A contemporary dance performance about humanity, inspired by and old Italian folk song called Bella Ciao.
pages.descriptionLong:
This is the flower of a Partisan, died for freedom. 

A contemporary dance performance about humanity, inspired by and old Italian folk song called Bella Ciao.


Stimulus, game

Reaction, addiction

Presence, empathy

Freedom, animality

The beyond.


Two dancers driven by their individual principles, two counterforces on a neverending cycle of breathing, being out of breath and reconfiguring. Mari Rosendahl’s duet piece focuses on the questions of how it feels to exist and whether one thing can exist without the other. Duetto takes influences and comments on world politics in the abstract context.


Work-in-progress performance have been seen in different spaces, which all have influenced the atmosphere of Aliveness.

pages.name: Tampere Philharmonic Orchestra: Symphonic Dances
pages.descriptionShort: Thomas Adès’s violin concerto Concentric Paths (2005) has quickly entered the repertoire of top soloists around the world. Swedish violinist Johan Dalene returns to Tampere after a four-year break.
pages.descriptionLong:
Dima Slobodeniouk, conductor 

Johan Dalene, violin 


Sebastian Fagerlund: Drifts 

Thomas Adès: Violin concerto, “Concentric Paths” 

Sergei Rahmaninov: Symphonic Dances 


Sebastian Fagerlund has become one of Finland’s most notable contemporary composers, known for music that evokes forces greater than ourselves. Drifts unleashes the full power of the orchestra, pulling the listener into deep, relentless ocean currents. Similar raw energy flows through Thomas Adès’s violin concerto Concentric Paths, which has quickly become a favourite among many top violinists. In Tampere, it will be performed by Swedish star Johan Dalene, making a welcome return as soloist with the Philharmonic. Sergei Rachmaninoff, then living in the United States, overcame his fear of the blank page one last time in 1940. Symphonic Dances, his final work, reflects nostalgia, longing, and the vivid presence of a life fully lived. 


Season series concert | includes an intermission | pre-concert talk at 6 PM


Tickets: adults 34 € / pensioners 26 € / students, unemployed and conscripts 16 € / children under 18 years 10 €


You can buy tickets from the Tampere Hall ticket office, Aplodi and the Lippupiste online store (Lippupiste adds service and order fees to the ticket prices, along with possible delivery and payment method charges).

pages.name: Afternoon of Fauns: Echoes on the Plains
pages.descriptionShort: Some of the most beloved works arise from vast, open landscapes: Dvořák’s quartet reflects the peaceful expanse of the prairie, while Sallinen’s variations echo the deep melancholy of a folk song.
pages.descriptionLong:
Béla Bartók: A Potpourri of Duos for Two Violins

István Szalay and György Balázs, violin


Aulis Sallinen: String Quartet No. 3, Op. 19, “Some Aspects of Peltoniemi Hintrik’s Funeral March"

Katri Nikkanen, violin, Lotta Laaksonen, violin, Kimmo Kivivuori, viola and Sampo Liukko, cello


Antonín Dvořák: String Quintet in E-flat major, Op. 97, "American"

Lotta Laaksonen and István Szalay, violin, Anne Korhonen and György Balázs, viola and Maija Juuti, cello


Boundless landscapes that spark the imagination thread through this program. Béla Bartók’s duos echo with the yearning tones of Hungarian folk songs, while Aulis Sallinen’s most celebrated quartet plunges into the mournful depths of an Ostrobothnian funeral march. Inspired by the vast prairies of the American Midwest and the melodies of Indigenous peoples, Antonín Dvořák composed his beloved “American” string quartet, now a cornerstone of the chamber music repertoire.


The concert is hosted by composer Minna Leinonen. The concert lasts about 2 hours including an intermission. 


Tickets: adults 18 € / pensioners 11 € / students, unemployed, conscripts and children under 18 yrs 7 €


You can buy tickets from the Tampere Hall ticket office, Aplodi and the Lippupiste online store (Lippupiste adds service and order fees to the ticket prices, along with possible delivery and payment method charges).

pages.name: Tampere Philharmonic Orchestra: Christmas concert
pages.descriptionShort: The Tampere Philharmonic Orchestra, Chief Conductor Matthew Halls, star soloists and the Tampere Philharmonic Choir bring Christmas spirit to life with Bach’s joyful Christmas Oratorio.
pages.descriptionLong:
Matthew Halls, conductor 

Soloists 

Tampere Philharmonic Choir  


Johann Sebastian Bach: Weinachts Oratorium (Christmas Oratorio): parts I-III and VI   

In 1734, Johann Sebastian Bach created one of his most beautiful sacred works, the Christmas Oratorio. The oratorio’s jubilant spirit, evoking the Bethlehem stable, shines through in its melodies. Unlike the Passions, the Christmas Oratorio was performed in six parts over six days in two churches. This year, four parts will be heard in one evening, with top soloists for the arias, the Tampere Philharmonic Choir, and the Tampere Philharmonic, conducted by Matthew Halls, bringing the season to a magnificent close with one of Baroque music’s finest achievements. 


Season series concert | intermission details to be confirmed


Tickets: adults 42 € / pensioners 32 € / students, unemployed, conscripts and children under 18 yrs 20 €

pages.name: Indeterminate
pages.descriptionShort:
Auli Kaartinen (1960–2024) photographs of the gender rebels of the 1980s.

Community Gallery Komuutti.
pages.descriptionLong:
Auli Kaartinen (1960–2024) was an information scientist and photographer. She began photographing her circle of friends in the late 1980s, when norms related to gender and sexuality began to be challenged. A counterculture was created in communities, where indeterminacy and outsideness created freedom and gave space.

 

In her photographs, Auli Kaartinen documented the everyday life and celebrations of her own circle. Auli Kaartinen took experimental self-portraits and photographed her friends in the studio. In her self-portraits, Kaartinen explored themes of gender, sexuality, power and death. She approached photography with ambition and developed her skills purposefully both behind the camera viewfinder and in the darkroom. Auli Kaartinen's photographs have been published in the books Uusin silmin (1996) and Julmia naisia (1989).

 

The exhibition is on display at the community gallery Komuutti, which organizes small-scale temporary exhibitions in collaboration with researchers, artists and other partners. Komuutti's name comes from the words "space for experimental museum activities". Despite its small size, Komuutti's exhibitions deal with big topics and the community gallery is an important channel for the museum in its work on behalf of human rights and sustainable development.


Accessibility information:

The route to the venue is barrier-free.

The museum's main entrance is at Väinö Linnan aukio at Väinö Linnan aukio 8.

There is space for escort vehicles to stop in front of the entrance and there is one barrier-free parking space next to the main door.

The nearest public transport stops are along Satakunnankatu, 200 meters from the museum.


There is a doorbell at the main entrance at Väinö Linnan aukio, but no door opening button.

The door is quite heavy to open and there are two doors in a row in the wind closet.

The museum's information desk is located on the street level, immediately after the main door, to the left.

There is a clothes rack in the street-level lobby, and there are locked lockers for storing items in connection with the rack.

There is also a wheelchair available for loan in the lobby.

The exhibition is located in the community gallery Komuutti on the second floor of the museum.

The exhibition floor is accessible by elevator. There is a floor map in the lobby of the exhibition floor, which shows the location of the different spaces. On the exhibition floor, the space is located in the middle of the main exhibition hall and access to the exhibition space is otherwise accessible, but there is a threshold at the door of the exhibition space and there are uneven floors in Komuutti. The lighting in the main exhibition hall is dim in places and there are various exhibition structures on the route that are not in a straight line with each other, but rather meander somewhat.

A gender-neutral accessible toilet is on the first floor of the museum.

Guide, assistance and hearing dogs are welcome in the museum.

There is no induction loop in the exhibition space.  

There is a Finnish introductory text about the exhibition in the exhibition space.

pages.name: Anna Niskanen's exhibition Oyster
pages.descriptionShort: The exhibition presents a collection of hand-printed photomontages that transform the Mältinranta gallery space into a water-filled room.
pages.descriptionLong:
Anna Niskanen’s solo exhibition Oyster presents a collection of hand-printed photomontages  that transform the Mältinranta gallery space into a water-filled room. Water surrounds us and flows within us – the water in our bodies supports us. The movement, shimmer, and sound of  moving water remind us of our origins. 

The materiality and surface of the large-scale, unique works emphasize the physicality and  labour of the process. The cyanotype, dating back almost 200 years, is a printing process in  which a light-sensitive emulsion is applied to paper, exposed to ultraviolet light, and finally washed with water. After exposure, the blue image appears when the chemical reaction forms  the Prussian blue pigment. 

Various waterscapes blend together in the exhibition space. While individual sheets appear  abstract, placing them side by side in their entirety reveals new images of the element. The  photographs—captured at sea, on shores, in streams, by waterfalls, and of puddles—serve as a  starting point for the artworks. The edited pictures of nature oscillate between memories and  imagination. 

The collages feature photographs taken during Niskanen’s residencies abroad, where she encountered different bodies of water. Niskanen has also travelled by sea: the movement from  one place to another can become a transitional space that offers a unique opportunity to  observe the surrounding environment and nature. Niskanen employs traditional methods of photography and printmaking to reflect on the significance of photography as a means of  preserving memories and as a source of imagination. 

The accompanying written story, by Helen Korpak, suggests viewing the works as suspended scenes played by natural forces. 

Anna Niskanen (b. 1990) is a Helsinki-based visual artist. Her works explore the limitations and  conditions of photography and alternative printing processes. In 2017, Niskanen completed her master’s degree in Photography at Aalto University. Her works have been featured in group and solo exhibitions, including the Mänttä Art Festival, Wäinö Aaltonen Museum, Lianzhou Foto Festival, Centre de la Photographie de Mougins, Hippolyte, and Institut finlandais. She is also one of the founding members of the Kosminen collective.

pages.name: Piia Rantakangas's exhibition The Curious
pages.descriptionShort: The exhibition is a small collection of my latest drawings. At the center of each work is a forest animal surrounded by vegetation. In my works, a large emphasis is placed on the dot-like drawing technique.
pages.descriptionLong:
The Curious -exhibition is a small collection of my latest drawings. At the center of each work is a forest animal surrounded by vegetation. The subjects for my works are usually selected according to which animal or plant fascinates me at that moment. Birds and mice have been a fairly familiar sight in my earlier works, but recently I have also been interested in insects and snakes, for example. My goal would be to occasionally bring into my works creatures that may arouse horror or disgust in some viewers. The inspiration for this is my previous fear of vipers, which over the years has turned into more of a fascination and interest. The drawing of a viper and swamp snakes could be considered a kind of main work of the exhibition, which is also the largest work I have drawn with a felt-tip pen to date.


A large emphasis in my works is on the dot-like drawing technique I use. In recent years, I have also used a lot of paper cutting in my works, which is also visible to some extent in the works in this exhibition. The patient way of working creates drawings that you can immerse yourself in without feeling rushed. There is a lot of noise in the world around us and the flood of information is enormous, which causes stress, irritation and difficulty concentrating for many. With my own long-term working method and the small details of my drawings, I strive to create works that would act as a counterbalance to such a world.


Piia Rantakangas (b.1993) lives and works in Tampere. Originally from Lehtimäki in South Ostrobothnia, the visual artist graduated from Kankaanpää Art School in 2017

pages.name: Villi kollekiivi: Rewilding
pages.descriptionShort: Villi kollektiivi's Rewilnding Exhibitions opens at Haihara Art Center's Stable.
pages.descriptionLong:
The Rewilding art exhibition at Haihara Stable brings together works by 7 different artists that deal with wildness in the environment and humanity.


The artists in the exhibition, Johanna Ali-Tolppa, Hannakaisa Hautamäki, Minna Lumiluoto, Terhi Mäkkylä, Pirje Seppälä, Terhi Ulonen and Pirjo Virtanen, have studied together at Pirkan Opisto, an adult art school. The theme of the exhibition is Rewilding, which describes actions to correct nature loss.


Rewilding is a global term for repairing nature loss where the original vegetation has lost its vitality, but other species can still flourish in the environment. On the other hand, the same phenomenon can be seen as an examination of a person's inner world and, for example, the process of creating a work of art. 


The artists in the exhibition also want to highlight the creativity and artistry that has developed through studying at the school, which has wildened their painting. Rewilding can also be an internal experience of the need to renew, release energy or let go of the inner self that is stuck in external demands. The exhibition asks; what died or disappeared because I had to make the choices I made before? The number of choices in an individual's life is often limited, you can't have everything, at least not at the same time, but is it possible to rewild something that has already seemed lost?

 

Haihara Art Centre, Stable (Haiharankatu 30)

June 7–29, 2025

Open Tue-Sun from 1 PM to 6 PM

Closed during Midsummer, June 20-22.

Free admission to the exhibition.

pages.name: Spartak Khachanov: The Impersonal
pages.descriptionShort: The Impersonal is an art project by Spartak Khachanov that depicts refugeehood and rootlessness in the Vantaa reception center. The work makes visible the everyday life of asylum seekers in Finland.
pages.descriptionLong:
The Impersonal is a long-term art project by photographic and media artist Spartak Khachanov. The work explores themes of migration and life in a refugee reception centre. The project is based on the artist’s own experiences as an asylum seeker living for two years in a refugee centre located in Vantaa, Finland, after arriving in the country as a political refugee in 2019.


War and forced migration have shaped Spartak Khachanov’s life from an early age. He was born in Azerbaijan, from where his family fled to Armenia and later to Ukraine. Over the course of his life, Khachanov has been forced to leave his home four times. His most recent flight began in 2019, when his art provoked strong reactions in far-right nationalists, he received death threats and became a target of the radical right-wing group C14. In 2021, he applied for political asylum in Finland and spent two years at a refugee centre in Vantaa while awaiting refugee status. During this time, Khachanov began systematically documenting his surroundings and it’s impact on the people living there.


In The Impersonal, Khachanov explores the refugee centre as a physical and psychological space. He documented his experience through photography, video, and sound recordings. The exhibition includes a photographic installation consisting of 1,400 disposable paper plates, each with a photo taken on an iPhone mounted in the centre. The images depict fellow residents, interior spaces, outdoor environments, and everyday objects from the refugee centre. The project’s title refers to the experience of invisibility and the erosion of identity: the refugee centre becomes a space where time stands still, and residents are pushed to the margins of society – trapped in a space between past and future. The work aims to shed light on the lived reality of those seeking refuge in Finland and raise questions about who refugees are, where they come from, and what kinds of situations they are fleeing.


“A refugee centre is like a black hole in the landscape. Time loses its meaning, and every day is the same. You were taken from your home country like garbage, and the new society is in no hurry to accept you – or even notice you. Refugees are left stuck between the past and the future. They cannot return, but their future is vague.”


Spartak Khachanov is an Armenian artist born in Azerbaijan and living in Finland whose work addresses political and societal issues such as war, instability, nationalism, and migration. He works with sculpture, installation, painting, photography, video, animation, and sound. His art has been shown in numerous exhibitions and festivals in Helsinki, Vantaa, Berlin, Madrid, New York, and Sofia, among others. His work has been featured in The Guardian, The Washington Post, Helsingin Sanomat, and Hyperallergic.

pages.name: Silja Tusa: What Is Left Behind
pages.descriptionShort: Silja Tusa's What's Left Behind exhibition explores memory and abandonment through collages assembled from a family's discarded photographs and edited by cutting, burning, painting and scratching.
pages.descriptionLong:
What Is Left Behind is a series of mixed media collages, created out of the artist’s family’s discarded album photographs. The series uses our society’s ever-changing relationship to photography as a framework for examining themes of memory, loss, and presence.


digital photo manipulation, the careful curation of social media and the new frontier of artificial intelligence generated images have chiseled away at our perception of the documentary nature of photographs. What Is Left Behind takes this abandonment of documentation in a different direction, replacing idealistic editing with analog photo manipulation, resulting in images resembling memories in all their haziness. The way we relate to the past is always evolving, our memories changing over time, some discarded along the way, the narrative of our identities forming and reforming throughout our lives. The series visualises these tendencies of the mind, warping the original photos beyond recognition and condensing a whole life into a curated selection of images.


The theme of loss is present throughout the works. By destroying photographs inherited from their grandparents, the artist releases the captured moments into the vastness of history, the photographed versions of the images’ subjects vanishing forever. This type of permanent disappearance seems frightening at first, but the pieces approach this loss through solace. It’s a wonderful thing to let go of past selves, to not have them haunt us through our digital footprints, to destroy an image knowing that a backup of a backup will never resurface.

 

The creation through destruction of the series acts as a dissenting voice in a world obsessed with eternal youth and perfection. Like molecules, the photographs break apart into atoms, reconverging into a new order. Death is required for birth, reminding us that nothing lasts forever, nor should it. Basking in the fleetingness of life gives an opportunity to to be fully present, the awareness of one’s finiteness acts as a catalyst to see what is truly important in life.


Silja Tusa (b. 1999) is a Tampere-based visual artist who works mainly with mixed media collage and photography. They graduated from the Tampere University of Applied Sciences in 2024 with a Bachelor’s in Fine Art. Tusa approaches each work from a place of honest subjectivity, weaving together personal experiences and universal themes. A recurring motif in Tusa’s work is the fleetingness of everything, the cycle of matter and life. This is reflected in their working process. Tusa creates their art mainly with recycled materials, destroying the old to create something new. They use a large variety of techniques, combining and playing with different materials, textures and pigments, resulting in unique pieces that are distinctly from Tusa’s hand.

pages.name: Landscape of a Century – Art from the OP Art Foundation collection
pages.descriptionShort: The Landscape of a Century exhibition presents artworks from the OP Art Foundation collection, featuring paintings and sculptures by Finnish artists, spanning over a hundred years.
pages.descriptionLong:
Exhibition theme

The Landscape of a Century exhibition presents artworks from the OP Art Foundation collection, featuring paintings and sculptures by Finnish artists, spanning over a hundred years. A specific theme consistent throughout the collection is Finnish nature, providing us with a link from the past to the present. Nature has inspired several generations of artists, and the depiction of nature in all its diversity is seen both in modern and older works of art.

In the exhibition, modern art pieces have been placed side by side with art from different eras, creating a rhythm of continuity. It is important to bear in mind that all art has been thought of as being contemporary in its own time.


OP Art Foundation

The OP Art Foundation was founded in 1987 to promote music and visual arts. To fulfil this purpose, the foundation owns and lends high-quality instruments to talented young musicians. The foundation also owns an art collection and provides pieces for exhibitions organised directly with art museums and in collaboration with the Finnish Fine Arts Foundations association.

The OP Art Foundation holds an important role in preserving Finnish cultural heritage. Its art collection is one of the largest private collections in Finland, comprising about 3,000 pieces and encompassing a wide and extensive selection of Finnish art history, including paintings, sculptures, graphics and textile art from the mid-1800’s to the present day.

The collection also constitutes an obligation to the foundation. The collection must be understood as being part of the Finnish art reserve, currently held and maintained by the OP Art Foundation. It is important to fulfil the obligation of maintaining the artworks to ensure that the power of their message is also preserved for future generations.


Kimmo Pyykkö Art Museum, 1st and 2nd floor

pages.name: Grumpy Girls - Class Struggles
pages.descriptionShort: Original drawings from Riina Tanskanen's comic book "Grumpy Girls - Class Struggles" (Into Publishing 2025).
pages.descriptionLong:
Cartoonist Riina Tanskanen's exhibition Grumpy Girls – Class Struggles examines the connections between economy, class and girlhood. The exhibition presents original drawings from the comic book Grumpy Girls 2 – Class Struggles (Into Kustannus 2025). Tanskanen's sweetly edgy comics question whose voice can be used to talk about the economy and society.


Grumpy Girls tells the story of relationships between girls in many different ways. Grumpy Girls defends equality and everyone's right to be exactly who they are.


Riina Tanskanen (born 1998) is a cartoonist and social critic from Tampere. The art account Tympeät tytöt has over 60,000 followers on Instagram and the comic book Tympeät tytöt – Aikuistumisriittejä (Into Kustannus 2021) was a bestseller. Tanskanen was awarded the State Prize for Information Disclosure in 2022. The exhibition at Werstas is her first museum exhibition.


Accessibility information

The route to the venue is barrier-free.

The museum's main entrance is at Väinö Linnan aukio, address Väinö Linnan aukio 8.

There is space for escort vehicles to stop in front of the entrance and there is one barrier-free parking space next to the main door.

The nearest public transport stops are along Satakunnankatu, 200 meters from the museum.


There is a doorbell at the main entrance at Väinö Linnan aukio, but no door opening button.

The door is quite heavy to open and the wind cabinet has two doors in a row.

The museum's information desk is located on the street level, immediately after the main door, on the left.

A coat rack is in the street level lobby, and there are lockable compartments for storing items next to the coat rack.

A wheelchair can also be borrowed in the lobby.

The exhibition is located in the exhibition hall called Kisälli on the second floor of the museum.

The exhibition floor is accessible by elevator. There is a floor map in the lobby of the exhibition floor, which shows the location of the different rooms. On the exhibition floor, the space is located next to the elevator lobby, to the front left when viewed from the elevators. Access to the exhibition space is accessible.

A gender-neutral, accessible toilet is on the first floor of the museum. There are only separate toilets on the exhibition floor for women and men, which are not accessible.

Guide, assistance and hearing dogs are welcome in the museum.

There is no induction loop in the exhibition space. 

The exhibition space has introductory texts in Finnish and English about the exhibition.

pages.name: Mineral Gallery
pages.descriptionShort: Selected stones from Tampere Mineral Museum, a public favourite, can be admired in a exhibition opening in Vapriikki's Gallery space
pages.descriptionLong:
The new exhibition is called the Mineral Gallery. Because the exhibition space is smaller than before, and the Mineral Museum's collection is very extensive, not all of the stones in the collection can now be exhibited. However, all of the most significant stone groups in the Stone Museum's collections will be on display, such as amethysts and other quartzes, chalcedony, fossils, sand roses, meteorites and of course all of the finest precious and jewelry stones from sapphires to amber. The exhibition will also feature touchable stone samples. You can also examine stone samples under ultraviolet light and search for fossils in the sand. The centerpiece of the exhibition will be the huge Stones in the Aquarium installation, familiar from the Power of Stone exhibition, presenting almost 70 stone species.

The Mineral Gallery will also be a temporary exhibition, and is intended to be on display until the summer of 2026. However, stone lovers need not worry, as the Stone Gallery is an important and spectacular stopover before the Mineral Museum's new and larger permanent exhibition, as soon as its space is freed up from the museum center's renovations and other temporary exhibitions.

The exhibition will also feature stones never before seen in Vapriikki. Some spectacular gems from the Mineral Museum's collections have been selected for display, which have not previously been exhibited in the museum center. Among these are precious stones such as fine rubies and precious opals, and slightly more special gems such as spodumene and zircon. Other spectacular new items will include bright green uvarovite and fine fish fossils selected from the collections' pearls. A couple of real mystery stones will also be on display, the names or types of which no one has yet been able to confirm. Maybe you are the one who will recognize these oddities from the stone world?
